[[World War II]] | events = [[Rising of the Priests]] {{Infobox designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = WHS | designation1_offname = | designation1_type = Cultural | designation1_criteria = i, vi | designation1_date = 1980 ([[World Heritage Committee#Sessions|4th session]]) | delisted1_date = | designation1_partof = [[Valletta|City of Valletta]] | designation1_number = [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/131 131] | designation1_free1name = State Party | designation1_free1value = {{MLT}} | designation1_free2name = Region | designation1_free2value = [[Lists of World Heritage Sites in Europe|Europe and North America]] | designation1_free3name = | designation1_free3value = }} }} The '''fortifications of Valletta''' ({{lang-mt|Is-Swar tal-Belt Valletta}}) are a series of [[defensive wall]]s and other [[fortifications]] which surround the capital city of [[Valletta]], [[Malta]]. The first fortification to be built was [[Fort Saint Elmo]] in 1552, but the fortifications of the city proper began to be built in 1566 when it was founded by [[List of Grand Masters of the Knights Hospitaller|Grand Master]] [[Jean Parisot de Valette|Jean de Valette]]. Modifications were made throughout the following centuries, with the last major addition being [[Lascaris Battery|Fort Lascaris]] which was completed in 1856. Most of the fortifications remain largely intact today. The city of Valletta, along with [[Nicosia]] in Cyprus, was considered to be a practical example of an [[ideal city]] of the Renaissance, and this was due to its fortifications as well as the urban life within the city.{{cite web|last1=Cosmescu|first1=Dragos|title=Nicosia|url=http://fortified-places.com/nicosia/|website=fortified-places.com|accessdate=11 July 2015}} The fortifications were well known throughout Europe by the 17th century, and might have influenced the designs of part of the [[Fortress of Luxembourg]].{{cite web|title=Luxembourg|url=http://www.fortified-places.com/luxembourg/|website=fortified-places.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222023008/http://www.fortified-places.com/luxembourg/|archivedate=22 February 2015}} In an 1878 book, Valletta was described as "one of the best fortified [cities] in the world."{{cite book|last1=Pembroke Fetridge|first1=William|title=The American Travellers' Guides: Hand-books for Travellers in Europe and the East, Being a Guide Through Great Britain and Ireland, France, Belgium, Holland, Germany, Austria, Italy, Egypt, Syria, Turkey, Greece, Switzerland, Tyrol, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Russia, Spain, and Portugal|date=1874|publisher=Fetridge & Company|page=517|url=https://books.google.com.mt/books?id=AhE2AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA517#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Today, Valletta's fortifications are regarded as the most important of the [[fortifications of Malta]],{{cite journal|title=Malta restores her historic fortifications|journal=Arx - International Journal of Military Architecture and Fortification|date=July 2011|volume=8|page=7|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/index.php/Journals/arx-journal-vol-8.html|accessdate=16 August 2015}} and they form part of a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]].{{cite web|title=City of Valletta|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/131|website=UNESCO World Heritage List|accessdate=16 August 2015}} ==History== ===Background=== The construction of a fortified city on the Sciberras Peninsula was first proposed in 1524, when the [[Knights Hospitaller|Order of St. John]] sent a commission to inspect the Maltese Islands. Back then, the only fortification on the peninsula was a militia watchtower built by the [[Crown of Aragon|Aragonese]] in 1488.{{cite web|title=Fort St. Elmo|url=http://heritagemalta.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/FORT-ST-ELMO.pdf|website=[[Heritage Malta]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206083119/http://heritagemalta.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/FORT-ST-ELMO.pdf|archivedate=6 December 2013}} The tower was strengthened in 1533, but the proposed city was not built since the Order focused on building the fortifications of [[Birgu]], which had become their base.{{cite book|last1=Zammit|first1=Vincent|title=Il-Gran Mastri - Ġabra ta' Tagħrif dwar l-Istorja ta' Malta fi Żmienhom - L-Ewwel Volum 1530-1680|date=1992|publisher=Valletta Publishing & Promotion Co. Ltd.|location=[[Valletta]]|page=22|language=mt}} In 1551, an Ottoman force briefly attacked Malta, and then [[Invasion of Gozo (1551)|sacked Gozo]] and [[Siege of Tripoli (1551)|captured Tripoli]], and as a result, the Order set up a commission to improve the island's fortifications. In 1552, the Aragonese watchtower was demolished and [[Fort Saint Elmo]] was built in its place. The fort played a significant role in the [[Great Siege of Malta]] of 1565. It eventually fell after a month of fierce fighting (in which the Ottoman general [[Dragut]] was killed). The knights held out in Birgu and Senglea until a relief force arrived, and the siege was lifted.{{cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=James|title=History's bloodiest siege used human heads as cannonballs|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-466818/Historys-bloodiest-siege-used-human-heads-cannonballs.html|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=7 July 2007}} ===Construction=== After the Order emerged victorious from the siege, it received financial support from Europe, which was used to construct the new capital city on the Sciberras Peninsula. The Italian engineer [[Francesco Laparelli]] was sent by the Pope to design the city's fortifications,{{cite book|last1=Eccardt|first1=Thomas M.|title=Secrets of the Seven Smallest States of Europe: Andorra, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, San Marino, and Vatican City|date=2005|publisher=Hippocrene Books|location=[[New York City]]|isbn=9780781810326|page=235|url=https://books.google.com.mt/books?id=gQFzO_v_uwwC&pg=PA235&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false}} which were designed along the [[Star fort|Italian bastioned system]].{{cite web|title=Valletta - 1566|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/index.php/Fortifications/valletta-1566.html|website=MilitaryArchitecture.com|accessdate=11 July 2015}} Laparelli's original design consisted of a bastioned [[enceinte]], with nine [[Cavalier (fortification)|cavaliers]] and a ditch. The city was to be designed along a [[grid plan]], and was to include a naval [[arsenal]] and a ''[[Manderaggio]]'' (a harbour for small ships). The city's first stone was laid by Grand Master [[Jean Parisot de Valette|Jean de Valette]] on 28 March 1566, and the new city was called ''Valletta'' in his honour. The city walls were among the first structures to be built within the city, and were largely complete by the 1570s. Some changes were made to the design while the city was being constructed, and only two cavaliers were constructed, while the arsenal and Manderaggio were never built. Fort St. Elmo, which had been severely damaged in the 1565 siege, was also rebuilt and integrated in the city walls. The city of Valletta officially became the capital city of Malta and the seat of the Order on 18 March 1571, although it was still unfinished.{{cite book|last1=Gaul|first1=Simon|title=Malta, Gozo & Comino|date=2007|publisher=New Holland Publishers|isbn=9781860113659|page=100|url=https://books.google.com.mt/books?id=Fevix8jSqg0C&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100#v=onepage&q&f=false}} By the end of the 16th century, Valletta was the largest settlement in Malta. ===Improvements and modifications=== [[File:GrandHarbourValletta1801.jpg|thumb|left|View of Valletta and the [[Grand Harbour]] in 1801]] In the 17th and 18th centuries, Valletta's fortifications were strengthened with the construction of various [[outwork]]s, consisting of four [[counterguard]]s along the land front, as well as a [[covertway]] and a [[glacis]]. The northern end of the peninsula, including Fort St. Elmo, was also enclosed in a bastioned enceinte (known as the [[Gregorio Carafa|Carafa]] Enceinte) in the late 1680s to prevent a landing from the sea. Despite the modifications, it was realized that the walls of Valletta were not strong enough to withstand a long siege. In 1635, construction of the [[Floriana Lines]] commenced, enclosing Valletta's land front. The Floriana Lines were also modified until the 18th century. Later on, the suburb of [[Floriana]] developed in the area between the Floriana Lines and the Valletta Land Front, and it is now a town in its own right.{{cite web|last1=Attard|first1=Sonia|title=The Valletta Fortifications|url=http://www.aboutmalta.com/history/vallettafort.shtml|website=aboutmalta.com|accessdate=10 June 2015}} The flanks of the city were further protected in the 17th and 18th century, with the construction of the [[Santa Margherita Lines]], [[Cottonera Lines]] and [[Fort Ricasoli]] on the [[Grand Harbour]] side, and [[Fort Manoel]] and [[Fort Tigné]] on the [[Marsamxett Harbour|Marsamxett]] side.{{cite web|title=Knights' Fortifications around the Harbours of Malta|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/982/|website=UNESCO Tentative Lists|accessdate=11 July 2015}} Further proposals, including construction of fortifications on Corradino and [[Ta' Xbiex]], were also made but were never implemented.{{cite journal|last1=Spiteri|first1=Stephen C.|title=Fort Manoel|journal=ARX Occasional Papers|date=2014|volume=4|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/index.php/Journals/arx-fort-manoel-occasional-papers-4.html|accessdate=11 July 2015}} ===French occupation and British rule=== [[File:Goats at Port Real Wellcome L0045092.jpg|thumb|[[City Gate (Valletta)#Third City Gate|Porta Reale]], constructed in 1853 and demolished in 1963]] The fortifications of Valletta first saw use during the [[French occupation of Malta|French invasion of Malta]] on 9 June 1798. The Order capitulated only three days later on 12 June, and Valletta and its fortifications were handed over to the French. Upon viewing the fortifications, [[Napoleon]] reportedly remarked "I am very glad that they opened the gate for us."{{cite web|title=Valletta - The Fortifications|url=http://romeartlover.tripod.com/Malta3.html|website=romeartlover.tripod.com|accessdate=28 August 2015}} A couple of months after the beginning of the French occupation, the Maltese people rebelled against the French and [[Siege of Malta (1798–1800)|blockaded them in the Harbour area]] with British, Neapolitan and Portuguese support. The French managed to hold out in Valletta until September 1800, when General [[Claude-Henri Belgrand de Vaubois|Vaubois]] capitulated to the British, who took control of the islands.{{cite web|title=The Conflict for Malta, 1798 – 1802|url=http://www.napoleon-series.org/military/battles/1798/c_Malta.html|website=napoleon-series.org|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=December 2008}} Various modifications were made to Valletta's fortifications during British rule. The most significant of these was the construction of [[Lascaris Battery|Fort Lascaris]] between 1854 and 1856. Other alterations included the addition of [[artillery battery|batteries]] and concrete gun emplacements, changes to parapets and their embrasures, and the construction of [[gunpowder magazine]]s. All three original Hospitaller gateways to Valletta were demolished, and two of them were replaced by larger gates.{{cite web|title=Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1572.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 September 2015|date=28 June 2013}} The British proposed the demolition of the fortifications a number of times in the 19th century. The first proposal was made by Major-General [[Henry Pigot]] at the beginning of the century.{{cite news|last1=Bonello|first1=Giovanni|title=Let’s hide the majestic bastions|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20121118/life-features/Let-s-hide-the-majestic-bastions.445894|accessdate=5 October 2014|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=18 November 2012}} In 1853, a proposal was made to demolish [[Saint James Cavalier]] to make way for a military hospital. In 1855, Sir [[John Lysaght Pennefather]] proposed the construction of a [[citadel]] on the high ground of the Sciberras peninsula, on the site of the Valletta Land Front and the surrounding area.{{cite web|title=Regimental Hospitals and Military Hospitals of the Malta Garrison|url=http://www.maltaramc.com/articles/contents/reghosp.html|website=maltarmc.com|publisher=British Army Medical Services And the Malta Garrison 1799 – 1979|accessdate=21 October 2015}} In 1872, the demolition of the city's outworks was proposed, while the demolition of the entire land front was suggested in 1882. Eventually, the fortifications were left largely intact, and the only part that was demolished was St. Madeleine's Lunette, which was located near the entrance to the city (on the site now occupied by the [[Triton Fountain (Malta)|Triton Fountain]]). The fortifications were eventually decommissioned between the late 19th or early 20th centuries. Some parts, such as Fort St. Elmo, Fort Lascaris and the [[Saluting Battery (Valletta)|Saluting Battery]], remained in use until after [[World War II]], with Fort St. Elmo being decommissioned in 1972.{{cite news|last1=Gusman|first1=George R.|title=Fort St Elmo|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120405/letters/Fort-St-Elmo.414180|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=5 April 2012}} The fortifications were included on the Antiquities List of 1925.{{cite web|title=Protection of Antiquities Regulations 21st November, 1932 Government Notice 402 of 1932, as Amended by Government Notices 127 of 1935 and 338 of 1939.|url=https://www.mepa.org.mt/file.aspx?f=2627|website=[[Malta Environment and Planning Authority]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6guMwmZDW|archivedate=20 April 2016}} In the 1960s, the 19th century [[City Gate (Valletta)#Third City Gate|Porta Reale]] was demolished to make way for a [[City Gate (Valletta)#Fourth City Gate|modern City Gate]].{{cite news|last1=Attard|first1=Chris|title=The gate triumphant|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20080824/opinion/the-gate-triumphant.222115|accessdate=11 July 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=24 August 2008}} ===Present day=== [[File:Malta - Valletta - Triq Girolamo Cassar - Herbert Ganado Gardens+SS Peter and Paul Counterguard 01 ies.jpg|thumb|left|Restoration works at St. Peter and St. Paul Counterguard in 2013]] The first plans to restore the fortifications of Valletta, along with those of [[Fortifications of Birgu|Birgu]], [[Fortifications of Mdina|Mdina]] and the [[Cittadella (Gozo)|Cittadella]], were made in 2006.{{cite news|last1=Zammit|first1=Ninu|title=Restoration of forts and fortifications|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20061212/opinion/restoration-of-forts-and-fortifications.32474|accessdate=10 June 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=12 December 2006}}{{cite news|title=A fortune on fortifications|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20080620/local/a-fortune-on-fortifications.213404|accessdate=10 June 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=20 June 2008}} Restoration started in 2010, with the project being described as "the biggest in a century". Squatters were evicted from public lands around the fortifications.{{cite news|last1=Ameen|first1=Juan|title=Restoration starts on Valletta bastions|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100201/local/restoration-starts-on-valletta-bastions.292182|accessdate=10 June 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=1 February 2010}} The upper part of Fort Saint Elmo has been restored, while its lower parts have been cleaned up.{{cite news|title=Updated - Upper Fort St Elmo restoration nears completion|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20141104/local/updated-upper-fort-st-elmo-restoration-nears-completion.542633|accessdate=10 June 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=4 November 2014}} The Chapel of St. Roche on St. Michael's Counterguard, which was bombed in World War II, was rebuilt in 2014 as part of the restoration.{{cite news|title=Counterguard Chapel Reconstructed|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/index.php/News/counterguard-chapel-reconstructed.html|accessdate=10 June 2015|work=MilitaryArchitecture.com|date=20 November 2014}} In 2011, the City Gate which had been built in the 1960s was demolished, and a [[City Gate (Valletta)#Fifth City Gate|new City Gate]] was completed in 2014.{{cite news|last1=Calleja|first1=Claudia|title=City Gate bites the dust|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110506/local/City-Gate-bites-the-dust.363924|accessdate=11 July 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=6 May 2011}} {{clear}} ==Layout== ===Land front=== [[File:Valletta Land Front 1858.jpg|thumb|center|700px|Detail from an 1858 painting by [[Edward Fanshawe]], showing the Valletta Land Front]] [[File:Malta - Valletta - Valletta Ditch + St. John's Bastion (City Gate bridge) 01 ies.jpg|thumb|St. John's Bastion]] The Valletta Land Front is the large bastioned enceinte enclosing the landward approach to the city. It consists of the following:{{cite book|last1=Meli|first1=Pavla Antonia|title=An Introduction to the Hospitaller Military Architecture of Valletta|date=1998|url=http://www.scribd.com/doc/12982353/The-Fortifications-of-Valletta-Malta-a-senior-school-project#scribd}} *St. Michael's Bastion, also known as Spencer's Bastion{{cite journal|last1=Simpson|first1=Donald H.|title=Some public monuments of Valletta 1800–1955|journal=Melita Historica|date=1958|volume=2|issue=3|page=157|url=http://melitensiawth.com/incoming/Index/Melita%20Historica/MH.02(1956-59)/MH.2(1958)3/orig03.pdf}} – a demi-bastion on the western extremity of the land front. Two windmills were built on it in 1674, but they were demolished in the 19th century.{{cite web|title=Windmill St Michael's Bastion 1|url=http://www.windmillsofmalta.nl/db.cgi?p=detail;r=19|website=The Malta Windmill Database|accessdate=11 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=Windmill St Michael's Bastion 2|url=http://www.windmillsofmalta.nl/db.cgi?p=detail;r=20|website=The Malta Windmill Database|accessdate=11 July 2015}} The bastion now forms part of [[Hastings Gardens]].{{cite web|title=St Michael Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1581.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. John's Curtain – the [[Curtain wall (fortification)|curtain wall]] linking St. Michael's and St. John's Bastions. It now forms part of Hastings Gardens.{{cite web|title=St John Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1580.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. John's Bastion – a large obtuse-angled bastion with a reconstructed [[bartizan|echaugette]] at its salient angle. It now forms part of Hastings Gardens.{{cite web|title=St John Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1573.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} **[[Saint John's Cavalier|St. John's Cavalier]] – a pentagonal [[Cavalier (fortification)|cavalier]] overlooking St. John's Bastion. It is now the embassy of the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta|SMOM]] to Malta.{{cite web|title=St John Cavalier - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1574.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *Porta Reale Curtain, also known as St. James Curtain – the curtain wall linking St. John's and St. James Bastions. The city's [[City Gate (Valletta)|main gate]] is located within the curtain wall.{{cite web|title=Porta Reale Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1576.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} The gate was rebuilt five times, with the present one being constructed between 2011 and 2014 to a design by [[Renzo Piano]]. [[File:St James Counterguard.jpeg|thumb|right|St. James Counterguard]] *St. James Bastion – a large obtuse-angled bastion with an echaugette at its salient angle. Its thick [[Parapet#Parapets in fortification|parapets]] with [[embrasure]]s have been dismantled. The bastion is occupied by the [[Central Bank of Malta]] and a car park.{{cite web|title=St James Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1577.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} **[[Saint James Cavalier|St. James Cavalier]] – a pentagonal cavalier overlooking St. James Bastion. It is now a cultural centre.{{cite web|title=St James Cavalier - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1575.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *Castile Curtain – the curtain wall linking St. James and St. Peter & Paul Bastions. Its parapet has been largely dismantled to make way for the road leading from Floriana to Valletta.{{cite web|title=Castile Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1578.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Peter and St. Paul Bastion – a two-tiered corner bastion on the eastern extremity of the land front. The upper part is now the [[Upper Barrakka Gardens]], while the lower part contains the [[Saluting Battery (Valletta)|Saluting Battery]].{{cite web|title=SS Peter and Paul Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1579.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} The 19th-century [[Lascaris Battery|Fort Lascaris]] is located below the bastion. The entire land front is surrounded by a deep ditch.{{cite web|title=Main Ditch - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1606.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} Remains of a flanking battery within the ditch were unearthed in 2012.{{cite web|title=Flanking battery discovered in Valletta Ditch|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/index.php/Conservation/flanking-battery-discovered-in-valletta-ditch.html|website=MilitaryArchitecture.com|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=25 February 2012}} [[File:Malta 230915 Valletta 06.jpg|thumb|St. Michael's Counterguard and a place-of-arms on Valletta's [[covertway]], as viewed from St. John's Curtain]] The bastions are further protected by the following outworks: *St. Michael's Counterguard – a three-tiered [[counterguard]] built in 1640 near St. Michael's Bastion. Its lower tier contains an echaugette at its salient angle, and a small chapel dedicated to St. Roche.{{cite web|title=St Michael Counterguard - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1602.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} The chapel was destroyed in World War II, but was rebuilt in 2014. *St. John's Counterguard – a pentagonal counterguard built in 1640 near St. John's Bastion. Its salient angle contains an echaugette, and it also contains a gunpowder magazine. It is currently used as a football ground.{{cite web|title=St John Counterguard - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1603.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Madeleine's Lunette – a [[Lunette (fortification)|lunette]] that protected Porta Reale Curtain and the entrance to the city. It was dismantled in the 19th century, and its site is now occupied by the [[Triton Fountain (Malta)|Triton Fountain]]. *St. James Counterguard – a pentagonal counterguard built in 1640 near St. James Bastion. Its salient angle contains an echaugette, and it also contains a gunpowder magazine. Its central platform houses the [[Central Bank of Malta]] annex.{{cite web|title=St James Counterguard - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1604.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Peter and St. Paul Counterguard – a two-tiered counterguard built in 1640 near St. Peter and St. Paul Bastion. Its salient angle contains an echaugette, and it also contains a gunpowder magazine and a concrete observation platform.{{cite web|title=SS Peter and Paul Counterguard - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1605.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} The outworks were surrounded by an advanced ditch, but only a part of it remains since most of it was filled in with rubble.{{cite web|title=Advanced Ditch - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1607.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} ===Marsamxett enceinte=== [[File:Valletta-panorama-fromsliema.jpg|thumb|center|700px|The enceinte along [[Marsamxett Harbour]]]] [[File:Malta - Valletta - Triq Sant Andrija - St. Andrew's Bastion 03 ies.jpg|thumb|Gun emplacement on St. Andrew's Bastion]] The enceinte along the side facing [[Marsamxett Harbour]] starts from St. Michael's Bastion of the Valletta Land Front, and ends at St. Gregory's Bastion of Fort St. Elmo. It consists of the following: *St. Andrew Tenaille – a small [[tenaille]] beneath St. Michael's Bastion.{{cite web|title=St Andrew Tenaille - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1612.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Andrew's Bastion – an asymmetrical pentagonal bastion. It is two-tiered, with its lower part originally containing the Marsamxett Gate, which was demolished in the early 20th century.{{cite web|title=St Andrew Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1582.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} A small [[faussebraye]] is located beneath the bastion. [[Ponsonby's Column]] was built on the bastion in 1838, but it was destroyed by lightning in 1864.{{cite news|title=The lost landmarks of Malta: Ponsonby’s Column, Valletta|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2014-01-26/arts-and-culture/the-lost-landmarks-of-malta-ponsonbys-column-valletta-3789324289/|accessdate=11 July 2015|work=[[The Malta Independent]]|date=26 January 2014}} *Manderaggio Curtain – the curtain wall linking St. Andrew's and San Salvatore Bastions. It was originally divided into two parts, to allow ships to enter the [[Manderaggio]], but the breach was walled up when work on the Manderaggio was abandoned.{{cite web|title=Manderaggio Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1584.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *San Salvatore Bastion – a flat-faced artillery platform. Various [[World War II]] air raid shelters were dug within the bastion.{{cite web|title=San Salvatore Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1585.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *German Curtain – a small curtain wall north of San Salvatore Bastion. Air raid shelters were also dug within its walls. It is sometimes referred to as a bastion.{{cite web|title=German Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1586.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Sebastian Curtain – a small curtain wall north of the Germain Curtain. Air raid shelters were also dug within its walls. It is sometimes referred to as a bastion.{{cite web|title=St Sebastian Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1587.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *English Curtain – a long curtain wall near St. Elmo Bay, overlooked by [[Auberge de Bavière]]. It contains the Jews' Sally Port and a number of air raid shelters. A reconstructed echaugette is located between the English and French Curtains.{{cite web|title=English Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1588.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *French Curtain – a long curtain wall near St. Elmo Bay, linked to [[Fort Saint Elmo]].{{cite web|title=French Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1589.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} ===Grand Harbour enceinte=== [[File:Malta Valletta Panorama 12.jpg|thumb|center|700px|The enceinte along the [[Grand Harbour]]]] [[File:Malta - Valletta - Triq il-Lanca+Xatt il-Barriera+Siege Bell War memorial+Lower Barrakka Gardens (MSTHC) 01 ies.jpg|thumb|St. Christopher Bastion]] The enceinte along the side facing the [[Grand Harbour]] starts from St. Peter and St. Paul Bastion of the Valletta Land Front, and ends at St. Ubaldesca Curtain of Fort St. Elmo. It consists of the following: *[[Lascaris Battery|Fort Lascaris]], also known as Lascaris Battery or Lascaris Bastion – a casemated battery near St. Peter & St. Paul Bastion, built by the British between 1854 and 1856. The [[Lascaris War Rooms]] are located nearby.{{cite web|title=Lascaris Battery - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1614.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *Marina Curtain, also known as Liesse Curtain – curtain wall linking St. Peter & St. Paul and St. Barbara Bastions. It originally contained Del Monte Gate, which was demolished and replaced by [[Victoria Gate (Valletta)|Victoria Gate]] in the 19th century.{{cite web|title=Marina Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1595.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Barbara Bastion – a flat-faced bastion with a low parapet. An echaugette is located at the bastion's south corner.{{cite web|title=St Barbara Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1594.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Lucia Curtain – curtain wall linking St. Barbara and St. Christopher Bastions.{{cite web|title=St Lucy Curtain - Valletta |url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1593.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Christopher Bastion – a two-tiered pentagonal bastion, today breached to make way for the Valletta [[ring road]].{{cite web|title=St Christopher Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1592.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} The upper part contains the [[Lower Barrakka Gardens]], while the lower part contains the Siege Bell War Memorial and the Monument to the Unknown Soldier. A low battery was built near the bastion in the 1680s, but most of it was dismantled to make way for the ring road.{{cite web|title=Grunenburg low battery - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1616.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Lazarus Curtain – curtain wall linking St. Christopher and St. Lazarus Bastions.{{cite web|title=St Lazarus Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1591.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *St. Lazarus Bastion – a flat-faced bastion containing several British gun emplacements and a magazine.{{cite web|title=St Lazarus Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1590.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} ===Fort Saint Elmo=== [[File:Malta Valletta2 tango7174.jpg|thumb|center|700px|[[Fort Saint Elmo]] with the entrance to Marsamxett to the right]] [[File:St. Elmo. Valletta. Fort.jpeg|thumb|Left Demi-Bastion of Fort St. Elmo]] [[File:Right Demi-Bastion of Fort St. Elmo.jpeg|thumb|Right Demi-Bastion of Fort St. Elmo]] [[Fort Saint Elmo]] is the oldest part of the city walls, and it commands the entrance to both the Grand Harbour and Marsamxett. The fort and the surrounding area consists of the following: *Upper St. Elmo – the original [[star fort]], consisting of two demi-bastions, two flanks and two faces, a [[Military parade|parade ground]], barracks and a large cavalier. *Vendôme Bastion – a bastion built in 1614 linking the French Curtain to Fort St. Elmo, containing an echaugette. After being surrounded by the Carafa Enceinte, it was converted into a magazine, and later an armoury. The bastion is now part of the [[National War Museum (Malta)|National War Museum]].{{cite web|title=Vendôme Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1613.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} *Carafa Enceinte – the bastioned enceinte built around the fort after 1687. It consists of the following bastions: **St. Gregory Bastion – an asymmetrical bastion with a long left face. It was altered by the British to house [[QF 6 pounder 10 cwt gun]]s.{{cite web|title=St Gregory Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1596.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} **St. Gregory Curtain – a curtain wall linking St. Gregory and Conception Bastions. It contains various British gun emplacements.{{cite web|title=St Gregory Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1597.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} **Conception Bastion, also known as Ball's Bastion – a small pentagonal bastion, containing a number of gun emplacements, magazines, and gun crew accommodation. Sir [[Alexander Ball]] was buried in the salient of the bastion.{{cite web|title=Conception Bastion - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1598.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} **Sta. Scholastica Curtain – curtain wall linking Conception and St. John Bastions. It contains a gun emplacement for a [[RML 12.5 inch 38 ton gun]], as well as other British modifications.{{cite web|title=Sta Scholastica Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1599.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} **St. John Bastion, also known as Abercrombie's Bastion – a large asymmetrical bastion at St. Elmo Point, the tip of the Sciberras Peninsula. The bastion contains several British gun emplacements and magazines.{{cite web|title=St John Bastion Caraffa - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1600.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} **St. Ubaldesca Curtain, also known as Abercrombie's Curtain – a long curtain wall linking St. John and St. Lazarus Bastions. It contains a number of British gun emplacements.{{cite web|title=Sta Ubaldesca Curtain - Valletta|url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1601.pdf|website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands|accessdate=11 July 2015|date=28 June 2013}} Some barrack blocks are located in the area between Upper St. Elmo and the Carafa Enceinte. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} '''Notes''' {{notelist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1572.pdf National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands] {{Valletta}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Valletta]] [[Category:City walls in Malta|Valletta]] [[Category:Castles and fortifications of the Knights Hospitaller|Valletta]] [[Category:Limestone buildings in Malta]] [[Category:National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands]] [[Category:16th-century fortifications]] [[Category:17th-century fortifications]] [[Category:18th-century fortifications]]
